turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: They'll get him! They'll get him!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Ssh!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'm coming!  Keep dead quiet. Don't even breathe.

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: I'll be right here. I won't leave you.

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: What's the idea?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Never mind! Just play dead.

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: Hey --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Shut up, you!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Are you all right, now?

turns.speaker: MOLLIE
turns.text: Yeah, I'm feelin' fine.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: I'm a messenger at the State House. This is from the Governor.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: What's from the Governor?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: The reprieve for Earl Williams.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: They were all standing around when he wrote it. It was after they got back from fishing.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Get the Governor on the phone!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: You can't get him on the phone. He's out duckshooting now.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Fishing! Duckshooting! How do you like that. A guy does nothing more strenuous for forty years than play pinochle -- he gets elected Governor and right away he thinks he's Tarzan!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Now, listen! You never arrived here with this -- reprieve. Get it?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Yes, I did, just now. Don't you remember?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: How much do you make a week?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: How much do you make a week? What's your salary?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Forty dollars.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Who? Me?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Who do you think!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Now, listen. There's a fine opening for a fellow like you in the City Sealer's office.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: The City Sealer's office!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: You mean here in the city?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Yes, yes!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: I couldn't work in the city. You see, I've got my family in the country.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: But you could bring 'em in here! We'll pay all your expenses.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: No, I don't think so.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: For heaven's sake, why not?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: I got two kids going to school there, and if I changed them from one town to another, they'd lose a grade.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: No, they wouldn't -- they'd gain one! And I guarantee that they'll graduate with highest honors!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: This puts me in a peculiar hole.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: No, it doesn't.  Now, remember: you never delivered this.  You got caught in the traffic, or something.  Now, get out of here and don't let anybody see you.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: But how do I know...?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Come in and see me in my office tomorrow. What's your name?

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Pinkus.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: All right, Mr. Pinkus, all you've got to do is lay low and keep your mouth shut. Here!  Go to this address. It's a nice, homey little place, and they'll take care of you for the night. Just tell 'em Fred sent you. And here's fifty dollars on account.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: You forgot to tell me what a City Sealer has to do.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I'll explain it tomorrow!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Is it hard?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: No! It's easy -- it's very easy!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Get out of here!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: You can't bribe me!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: They wouldn't take it.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: You're insane!

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: Here's the picture of my wife.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: A very fine-looking women.

turns.speaker: PINKUS
turns.text: She's good enough for me! And if I was to go home and tell my wife --

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I understand perfectly, Mr. Pinkus, and as long as I am Mayor --

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: If you ask us, no. If you ask the state alienists, the answer is yes.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: It's a simple story. Earl Williams works for the E.J. McClosky Manufacturing Company as a bookkeeper for fourteen years. He starts in at twenty dollars a week and gradually works his way up to twenty-two fifty. A year ago the McClosky Company goes out of business and Williams loses his job.  Take it away, Fred Wilson!

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Well, well -- Miss Mollie Malloy.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Hello, Mollie.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Look out!

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Look out where you're aiming, will you?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Sure, Mollie, you never looked better in your life.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Yeah, hold the line. Hey, this looks good. An old lady just called the detective bureau and claims Williams is hiding in her cellar. Well - we've looked every other place. Want to go out on it?

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Get the cops, somebody.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Come on, fellas.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: There she is!

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Say, Hildy...

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: What's your hurry?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: We want to see you.

turns.speaker: MCCUE
turns.text: Williams put up a desperate struggle but the police overpowered --

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: -- tried to shoot it out with the cops but his gun wouldn't work, so --

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well -- Williams goes a little balmy and begins making speeches on a plan he's got to save the world. Only he makes his speeches, usually, on a very busy street and neglects to get a license for it. Well, the cops let him alone as much as they can because he's harmless and they're kinda sorry for him. But one day he decides to hold a meeting right in the middle of a Veteran's Parade and the cops chase him. He gets scared and goes into hiding.  Come in, Dave Schwartz.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: His Honor, the Mayor, now comes out with a statement that Earl Williams is a dangerous character in the employ of two or three foreign governments and the police are going to get him dead or alive. Somebody sends out a tip that this guy is hiding in Molly Malloy's joint. And this colored policeman, Daniels, goes over to pick Williams up. Williams has read the papers, thinks the cop is going to kill him and shoots first. That is all.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Baldwin -- his name is.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: I give that marriage six months.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Who? Hildy Johnson? She just stepped out. She'll be back in a second. Who? Oh, Mr. Baldwin. Well, if you'll hang on a minute, she ought to be right in. All right.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Baldwin. The blushing bridegroom -- himself.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: What's he want?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Wants Hildy -- and sounds very excited.

turns.speaker: SCHWARTZ
turns.text: The door was locked.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: She and Mollie were talking.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Henry Chapman's daughter. It was Sheila. I remember her from last year.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: So it was. Sheila. This boy will go far.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Can I try?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Put your hand on mine, get the knack of it.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Never let a rat creep up on you.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I think you hit him, Grandpa. He was limping when he ran off.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: That was a googly!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: You're a dark horse, bowling googlies at your age. Toss me up another.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: No, you're out, Grandpa. It's my turn.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Want to know why they're called Faith, Hope, Grace and Charity?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Your grandmother. She named them after virtues I lack. That's marriage for you.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: This is going too far, young man.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But Grandpa, you said...

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: I concede I was insistent, but how the Devil...

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Give him the you-know-what.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Very well, Grandpa.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: You miserable little tripe-hound. I'm the one who should be fed up, sacrificing my last sup of black market petrol to take you to school.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I have to live in Rosehill Avenue as well.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Only till they get you into the local school.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: With Mrs. Evans. I hate her.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: You'll be at home for the weekends. Now shut up, or walk.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's true.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: You're much more convincing when you're making it up.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Grandpa, if you think of something hard enough, can you make it happen?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER GEORGE
turns.text: Apparently so.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Pauline's mum got killed.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: No, she didn't.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Yes, she did, didn't she?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: What are you doing here? This is our territory

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Looking for shrapnel.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I never was.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Yes, you was. Make him talk.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I know a secret.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The Germans are dropping men on bomb sites.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: My uncle's in the War Office. He said, Don't go on the bomb sites. "Boys are going missing all the time."

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: They're not.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: You want to join our gang?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I don't mind.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Do you know any swear words?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Say them.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Well go on then. You can't join if you can't answer.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I only know one.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: That word is special. That word is only for something really important. Now, repeat after me... Bugger off.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Bugger off.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Sod.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Sod.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Bloody.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Bloody.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Now put them together. Bugger off, you bloody sod.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Bugger off, you bloody sod.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: OK. You're in.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: They pulled them up from all the crossroads, so when the Germans land they'll lose their way.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Won't they have maps?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: They'll have to go to a shop to buy a map, stupid. Then they'll give zemselves avay viz ze vay zay tork.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: He's never going to come back. He's gone off to be a soldier and Mummy doesn't even know.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It doesn't matter, I can drive the car home.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You wouldn't.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Would.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You couldn't.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Could.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Go and ask her if she wants to play.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Ask her yourself.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You do it. You're a girl.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Tell them about Pauline's mum.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Not now. They wouldn't believe me.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Bruce, look! Dad got some German jam.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: We thought it was poison.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: I suppose they're still learning, that's why they keep moving about.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's easy. I've done it.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Who with?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Pauline.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Liar. Mummy keep still and Daddy moves on top of her. That's what they do when they know how.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I did see them. I did.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: He's the worst liar.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: You're the biggest fibber.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's dinner time. It really is. Cross my heart.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: The next one is ours. Either it hits us or it goes past us.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: ...and four and five...

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Please God. Not on us. Drop it on Mrs. Evans. She's a cow.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: ...and six...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Can't we just see the end?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: They've got the real thing outside.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's not the same.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Mind that shrapnel DAWN thrusts a brass regimental hat badge in BILL'S face.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: I'm starting my own collection.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's Canadian. Where'd you get it?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Well, I'm not having any. Even if it's not poisoned. I don't think it's right. It's not patriotic.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You don't like jam. You hate jam. You never eat jam.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: That's not the point.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: You did that for me, and on the last day of your holidays?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, for the baby, really.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Thank you Billy, from the baby and me.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Crocodiles! Aah!

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: The sodding water table.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But Dad, It's the News.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Thanks, son. I can hear it. I'm not sleeping, just closing my eyes.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Now, the googly looks like a leg break, but it's really an off break. Got it? Like this.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's like telling fibs.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: That's it. When you tell a lie, you hope to get away with it. When someone else does, you want to find them out. A good batsman will spot a googly. A good bowler will hide it. Always remember that, son.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You said that last year, Dad.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: The land and the King are one, my son. If he stutters we falter. He's getting batter, and so are we.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Big Berthas, shelling France. Twenty-five-mile range, they have.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: They send over a few every day, to let them know we're still here. Each shell costs as much as a Ford 8.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Who pays for them?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: We will, you will, for the rest of our lives?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: It was great for me, how was it for you.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: A bit too quick.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Well. Now we can do it slow. Are those some kind of stockings you're wearing?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: They might be.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I mean, no suspenders. They just kinda' disappear up your ass.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Take it away. I know your husband's been away a long time, but....

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Don't be so cheeky, Bruce.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Boy, that was some air-raid.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Air-raid?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Didn't you feel the house rock? You must have seen all those shell bursts.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: We're not supposed to say, but we're being shipped out tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I don't know?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: You do, you do. You're just not saying.

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: I swear I don't know.  Here's your Christmas present.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: You expect me to spend the rest of the war sitting at home staring at a ring? And you'll meet some French girl who can speak your own language. No thank you!

turns.speaker: BRUCE
turns.text: Please yourself.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Could you seal it over with hot pitch, Clive? Caulk it like the hull of a ship.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Thanks. I hope you can come for the launching.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: ...It was a toss-up. His company went to India, mine went to France. Flip of a coin.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: ...two Indians to fan me all night. The heat.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: ....buried In a shell-hole for thee days, while he's out there playing polo and sticking pigs.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: And Jim.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: What's left of him. He'll never see outside of the Star and Garter.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Root it out Clive... the thought of it, before it takes hold.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Weeds will grow, Mac.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Consider Grace, the kids. I love them like my own. And you.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Kiss me Hardy.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: You're a mug, Clive. We did our bit in the Last Lot.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: If King and Country call, Mac, you go as soon as I will.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: What did we know? We were seventeen.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: I heard the drum and fife yesterday, Mac, marching past.  Made my hair stand on end.  I thought, I've been asleep for twenty years.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: What kind of war is this Mac?  Up there in Cumberland, we never see an air-raid. The worst problem I have is getting a new typewriter ribbon. When I rode in against the Turks, I knew what it was about.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Did you? You thought you did. We've been gypsed, all our lives. Look at your street.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: What about it?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Rosehill Avenue. No roses. No hill. And it's certainly not an avenue.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: You need trees for an avenue.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: There was talk of planting some when we first came.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Propaganda. We've been had.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: How's your war, Mac?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Never done better. On the fiddle. Like everyone else.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Except the servicemen.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Naturally.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: I don't understand. Is there any point to it?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: There is all right. This Hitter fellow. We've got to winkle him out. And get shot of some of our lot at the same time.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: You always were, Clive. Steady the Buffs.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Bugger the Buffs.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Don't panic!  Keep your head!

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: I will if you will!

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: So you're going to be a grandfather.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: And I'm still just a lad myself.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Don't bother to grow up. It's no fun at all.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Here's to music. And absent friends.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: And absent bridegrooms!

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: And the bride.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: No Turks.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: We didn't know that. It was a suicide mission. Machetes against artillery. Volunteers only.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: They'd gone.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: We all had to write a last letter home.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: And it was the last. Hasn't written a letter since. Not even a birthday card.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Has Sue got it right?

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You joined up.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Oh, that.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I wish you could have told me yourself.  Oh, Grace, it's not for long. They say it'll be over by Christmas.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: And what's that?

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Jam.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: We don't know anything about it

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Well, it's off ration. We know that.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: How do we know they didn't plant it there? They know we're mad on jam.  They could poison half the country.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: It looks....foreign.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Jam is jam! It's just jam!

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Taste it. Why don't you taste it?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You taste it.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You mean they let you go through the officer training course and then said you were too old for a commission?

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: That's it.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Why didn't they say that before you started?

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: I wasn't too old when I started the course. I was too old when it finished.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: What are you going to be then?

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: A clerk. I'm doing a typing course. I'll be typing for England.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: When do you think you'll get leave again?

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Not till Christmas, I don't suppose.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: I'm glad you didn't send them to your aunt.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I've had a letter from her. They've moved house.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Where to?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I've found a bungalow to rent up the towpath, Clive. I never want to leave the river again. The children have had such a wonderful summer.

turns.speaker: CLIVE
turns.text: Fair enough.  The river.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I doubt if a few bombs would wake up Dawn on a Sunday morning.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: This phoney war get's on my nerves. If we're going to have a war, I wish they'd get it started.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Just ignore her, Mac.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: You know it? It must be an old one.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Ancient. Have you finished your homework?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: After this dance.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: He always knows.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Half the time he's bluffing.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: What would we do if a German came into the house?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Don't be silly, Dawn.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Well, why do you always bring the carving knife in here?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Tell me the truth. You had to get married, didn't you? Because of me.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: The ideas you get in your head.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: That's why you never liked me. I'm different from you. Well, everything's different now, so it doesn't matter. So there.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I won't have this vulgar talk in my house.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: It's only a joke, Mummy. I'm fifteen. I'm still at school. I want to be a nun when I grow up.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: And where do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: Out.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You go to bed this minute and take off that lipstick.

turns.speaker: DAWN
turns.text: No, I won't.
